channel.title: Which distro?
channel.description: Yeah, not this topic again. So anyway, I'm going to buy a CD so I can burn an ISO image to it. Before I do so, any recommendations for which distro I should use and why? I have my Ubuntu download still here with me by the way. :)

item.title: Which distro?
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

[quote=“Speljohan, post:10, topic:368257”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=464409.msg3438633#msg3438633 date=1292957956]

[quote author=Pwnd link=topic=464409.msg3438596#msg3438596 date=1292955020]

I just installed Ubuntu on my laptop, lovin’ it already. It boots 999999x faster than Vista.
[/quote]People still use Vista?

Obviously not, he said he is using Ubuntu.
[/quote]I use Vista… I have one of those builds where Windows 7 runs very poorly, and Vista works much better on.[/quote]Well that’s kind of awkward. Legacy hardware/software?

Read full topic

item.title: Which distro?
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

for an absolute starting-out distro, something in the ubuntu family would be good (crunchbang is fairly lightweight, but you can always use ubuntu/xubuntu/kubuntu)
a potentially more daring and less hold-your-hand distro worth trying is fedora, although i haven’t used it since fc9. the only outstanding negative part about this is the inevitable case where rpm bites you in the ass.

arch is a nice distro, very minimal and flexible. you might want some experience with linux in general if you want to use this without too many headaches, but it isn’t terribly difficult to get used too.

really, it depends on how much effort you are willing to put into becoming familiar with it, and how quickly you can adjust to something like this. lots of distros are excellent for starting with, however if you plan on making an informed ‘life choice’, i think you should start with somethat that doesn’t have everything ever automagically (cough ubuntu). if you’re up to it, try out debian. ubuntu is based on debian and uses debian’s package manager (dpkg, apt is a higher level tool that (tries to) save you from smacking yourself by screwing up). debian is still a pretty user friendly distro, relatively easy to install (using the installation guide of course, and for post installation there’s the debian wiki, and google as always). the best way to starting learning is to ‘just do it.’
if you don’t have another computer to use for reading documentation, forget it: just install ubuntu or something.

others to look into down the line (if you don’t start with one of them): debian, gentoo, knoppix+variants, slackware+variants

also, if you have a flash drive (at least 1GB), and your motherboard supports booting from USB, it’s a really good idea to use that for installation instead (considering you don’t have a stack of cds). you might want to jump around a lot.

Read full topic

item.title: Which distro?

item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

Beginner: CrunchBang
Experienced: ArchLinux
